awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms for multi-modal gaze stabilization in Drosophila
awd_abstract_narration:
Moving animals often use vision to determine where they are and where they are going. However, the scene in an animal's eyes only makes sense if it knows its own body position and movements. While they are moving, animals can also predict how their senses will be affected by their own movements. For example, as a human walks, his eyes bounce up and down with his steps, but he does not see this motion because his brain predicts and ignores this self-generated visual information. Though much is known about how this process works in a single sense organ, less is known about how multiple senses work together to do this. In many animals, the inner ear monitors the position and movement of the body. However, the inner ear is inside the head and difficult to study and manipulate. This project will take advantage of animals with rotation sensors on the outside of their bodies to observe how these organs influence behavior.  In flies, specialized organs called halteres detect body movements and these structures are located outside the body near the wings.  This research will measure changes in fly behavior that occur when the sensory information coming from the haltere is changed and when it does not match information gathered through vision. This work will show how multiple senses are integrated with the animal's own behavior to guide movement. By examining how the brain combines multiple sensory inputs and anticipates the consequences of its own behaviors, this work will uncover mechanisms of the brain's function that can be applied to other species and that can be used to understand biological brains and engineer algorithms for moving machines. The project will also be incorporated into a series of workshops at an all-girls high school with the goal of improving quantitative and computer coding skills in female students. 

Distinguishing between self-generated and externally generated body movements is a central challenge for the nervous system. Efference copy, a neural signal of opposite sign to expected sensory input, is a possible mechanism for this distinction. Efference copies have been observed in single sensory systems, but how might they function in a multi-sensory context? Using an animal with a well-understood visual system and an easily-accessible mechanosensory organ, these experiments will investigate how these two sensory modalities combine during voluntary and involuntary movements.  In flies, body rotations are detected by specialized mechanosensors called halteres. These are modified hindwings that perform a function similar to the mammalian vestibular system. This project will investigate the integration of haltere information, visual information, and motor commands through quantitative behavioral analysis of flying flies. Flies will fly under different conditions: flight with imposed body rotations (tethered to a motor), flight with free, self-generated rotations (tethered to pins suspended between magnets), and rigidly tethered flight (no body rotations) with imposed movements of the haltere. The fly's head movement behavior will be observed under these conditions, and the behavior of intact flies will be compared to flies with their mechanosensory halteres removed or manipulated. Finally, information theoretic analysis will be used to quantify the flow of information in the visual and mechanosensory systems and construct a theoretical framework that can be used to understand how information about body rotations is integrated with visual information to control posture and gaze. Taken together, these experiments and model will demonstrate how two sensory modalities are combined and integrated with motor feedback during flight.  Broader impacts include workshops to broaden experience for young women in quantitative and computer coding skills and presentation of the work to various non-scientific audiences. Work completed here has application to the field of robotics and the development of higher quality autonomous aerial robotics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Moving animals, including humans, need information about their body position and movement in space (proprioception) to create coordinated, purposeful movements. Humans and other vertebrates collect much of their proprioceptive information using the vestibular organ of the inner ear, which senses the head’s movements and rotations. However, these organs are internal and difficult to manipulate, which makes them challenging to study. Flies, which move at high speeds and in three dimensions, carry out much of their proprioception using two organs called halteres. Halteres are modified, club-shaped hindwings that flap in time with the lift-generating front wings and possess hundreds of sensory cells at their base. If the halteres are removed, flies can still take off, but they are unable to maintain stable flight. We asked: how does the haltere signal changes in the body’s motion to the fly’s nervous system and muscles, and how does the fly adjust its wing and head movements in response? Additionally, how does the fly process haltere information and visual information at the same time?

 

To answer these questions, we filmed the wing and head movements of tethered, flying flies with high-speed video cameras. Using electromagnets, we changed the size or the speed of the haltere’s motion. We also used an array of LEDs to provide a visual stimulus to the fly.

 

We found that changing the amplitude of the haltere’s flapping by applying the electromagnet directly changed the amplitude of the wing’s flapping. Further, we found that we could predict the wing amplitude response to a combined haltere and visual stimulus by simply adding the response to the haltere stimulus alone and the response to the visual stimulus alone. Thus, we showed that the circuits that drive the fly’s wing linearly combine vision and haltere stimuli. When we took the same approach to predict the fly’s head movements, however, we found that vision was dominant.

 

In a second project, we changed the frequency of the haltere. This is an unnatural stimulus that allowed us to determine how the wing and head would move if the timing relationship between the head and the wing were disrupted. We found that the wing movements become unstable, exhibiting “wing hitches” that are short, rapid changes in wing amplitude. Adding a visual stimulus did not change the wing’s stability, showing that haltere input that is synchronous with the wing is necessary for the wing to function properly.

 

In another project, we tethered the fly to a small servo motor and rotated the fly’s body in an unpredictable way. We did this in intact flies and in flies with their halteres removed, and we also provided a visual stimulus. Though we are still analyzing data from this project, we have found that haltere-removed flies could still respond to body motions by adjusting their gaze; the halteres are not the only means by which they sense rotation. However, these gaze adjustments were smaller and slower than those in intact flies.

 

Taken together, our results reveal some of the mechanisms by which the fly’s neural circuits collect information from multiple sensory modalities and use it to respond to their environment.

 

This grant was instrumental in training six students (graduate and undergraduate) for STEM careers. It was the main source of funding for two graduate students who are now pursuing careers in biology research. The PI and these graduate students also mentored several undergraduates, who received hands-on training in several aspects of research, including hypothesis generation, data collection, electronics troubleshooting, stimulus design, computer coding, data analysis, and presentation. Three undergraduates, two graduate students, and one technician presented their results at national and/or international meetings, with ten presentations in total. The grant resulted in seven published papers, with at least two more in preparation.

 

This grant also broadened participation in science through education, training, and outreach activities. The PI and trainees presented workshops on using computer code in the life sciences to students at an all-girls high school (women are still underrepresented in the quantitative subfields of life sciences), and we gave demonstrations of the experimental flight arenas at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History. We also trained four high school students in the research lab, who are now using their skills in STEM majors at four-year universities.
